revision.comment: Rescuing 5 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.2.4)
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox hurricane season | Basin=SPac | Year=1996 | Track=1995-1996 South Pacific cyclone season summary.jpg | First storm formed=January 12, 1996 | Last storm dissipated=March 28, 1996 | Strongest storm name=Beti | Strongest storm pressure=935 | Strongest storm winds=90 | Average wind speed=10 | Total depressions=6 | Total hurricanes=4 | Total intense=1 | Fatalities=2 | Damages=5.6 | five seasons=[[1993–94 South Pacific cyclone season|1993–94]], [[1994–95 South Pacific cyclone season|1994–95]], '''1995-96''', [[1996–97 South Pacific cyclone season|1996–97]], [[1997–98 South Pacific cyclone season|1997–98]] | South Indian season=1995–96 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season | Australian season=1995–96 Australian region cyclone season }} The '''1995–96 South Pacific cyclone season''' was one of the least active [[South Pacific tropical cyclone season]]'s on record, with only four [[tropical cyclones]] occurring within the South Pacific Ocean to the east of [[160th meridian east|160°E]].{{cite web|deadurl=no |year=1996 |author=Australian National Tidal Facility |accessdate=February 19, 2012 |url=http://www.sprep.org/att/publication/Retro/newsletters/SP%20Sea%20Level%20and%20Climate%20Change%201-3.pdf |title=The South Pacific Sea Level and Climate Change Newsletter |archivedate=February 19, 2012 |publisher=South Pacific Regional Environment Program |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/65ZvFepMn?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sprep.org%2Fatt%2Fpublication%2FRetro%2Fnewsletters%2FSP%2520Sea%2520Level%2520and%2520Climate%2520Change%25201-3.pdf |df=mdy }}{{cite report|title=Tropical Cyclone seasonal summary 2000-01|accessdate=June 10, 2011|author=RSMC Nadi — Tropical Cyclone Centre|url=http://www.met.gov.fj/documents/TC_Seasonal_Summary_00-011188357007.pdf|publisher=Fiji Meteorological Service|year=2002}}{{cite web|title=Tropical Cyclone Guidance for Season 2010/11 for the Fiji and the Southwest Pacific |archivedate=February 27, 2012 |url=http://www.met.gov.fj/2010_2011%20TC%20Guide.pdf |publisher=Fiji Meteorological Service |date=October 26, 2010 |accessdate=July 31, 2011 |author=Climate Services Division |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/65kvh9FwY?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.met.gov.fj%2F2010_2011%2520TC%2520Guide.pdf |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} The season officially ran from November 1, 1995 until April 30, 1996.{{cite web|title=Tropical Cyclone Operational Plan for the South Pacific and South-East Indian Ocean 1999|accessdate=August 15, 2008|publisher=World Meteorological Organization|year=1999|author=RA V Tropical Cyclone Committee|url=http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/tcp/documents/doc/Op-pln99.doc}} The first storm developed on January 12, while the last one dissipated on April 2. During the season the most intense tropical cyclone was Severe Tropical Cyclone Beti, which reached a minimum pressure of 935 hPa (27.61 inHg) as it affected New Caledonia. After the season ended Beti's name was the only name to be [[List of retired South Pacific tropical cyclone names|retired]] from the [[List of tropical cyclone names#South Pacific|tropical cyclone naming lists]] and was replaced with Bune, after it inflicted over 5.6 million (USD) worth of damage to Australia, Vanuatu, New Caledonia and New Zealand.{{cite report|title=Tropical Cyclone Operational Plan for the South Pacific and South-East Indian Ocean 2010|url=http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/tcp/documents/TCP-24_RAVOpPlan_2010.pdf|format=PDF|type=|accessdate=July 30, 2011|author=RA V Tropical Cyclone Committee|publisher=World Meteorological Organization|date=July 1, 2011}} During the season, tropical cyclones were officially monitored by the [[Regional Specialized Meteorological Center]] (RSMC) in [[Fiji Meteorological Service|Nadi, Fiji]], and the [[Regional Specialized Meteorological Center#Tropical cyclone warning centers|Tropical Cyclone Warning Centers]] (TCWC) in [[Bureau of Meteorology|Brisbane, Australia]] and [[Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited|Wellington, New Zealand]].{{cite report|year=1999|title=Tropical Cyclone Operational Plan for the South Pacific and South-East Indian Ocean|accessdate=February 27, 2012|author=RA V Tropical Cyclone Committee|publisher=World Meteorological Organization|url=http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/tcp/documents/doc/Op-pln99.doc}} Throughout the season the United States Navy also monitored the basin and issued unofficial warnings, through its [[Joint Typhoon Warning Center]] (JTWC) and Naval Pacific Meteorology and Oceanography Center (NPMOC).{{cite web|page=240|publisher=United States Navy, United States Air force|year=1998|url=http://www.usno.navy.mil/NOOC/nmfc-ph/RSS/jtwc/atcr/1996atcr.pdf|author=Joint Typhoon Warning Center|author2=Naval Pacific Meteorology and Oceanography Center|accessdate=June 16, 2011|title=1996 Annual Tropical Cyclone Report}} Tropical cyclones that were located between 160°E and 120°W as well as the Equator and 25°S were monitored by RSMC Nadi while any that were located to the south of 25°S between 160°E and 120°W were monitored by TCWC Wellington. During the season the JTWC issued warnings on any tropical cyclone that was located between 160°E and 180° while the NPMOC issued warnings for tropical cyclones forming between the 180° and the American coast. RSMC Nadi and TCWC Wellington both used the [[Australian Tropical Cyclone Intensity Scale]], and measured windspeeds over a 10-minute period during the season, while the JTWC and the NPMOC measured sustained windspeeds over a 1-minute period. __TOC__ {{Clear|right}} ==Seasonal summary==
ImageSize = width:825 height:200 PlotArea = top:10 bottom:80 right:20 left:20 Legend = columns:3 left:30 top:58 columnwidth:270 AlignBars = early DateFormat = dd/mm/yyyy Period = from:01/01/1996 till:01/04/1996 TimeAxis = orientation:horizontal ScaleMinor = grid:black unit:month increment:1 start:01/01/1996 Colors = id:canvas value:gray(0.88) id:GP value:red id:td value:rgb(0.5,0.8,1) legend:Tropical_Disturbance/Tropical_Depression_(TD) id:c1 value:rgb(0,0.98,0.96) legend:Category_1_=_63–87_km/h_(39–54_mph)_(1) id:c2 value:rgb(0.80,1,1) legend:Category_2_=_88–142_km/h_(55–74_mph)_(2) id:c3 value:rgb(1,1,0.80) legend:Category_3_=_143–158-km/h_(75–98_mph)_(3) id:c4 value:rgb(1,0.56,0.13) legend:Category_4_=_159–204_km/h_(99–127_mph)_(4) id:c5 value:rgb(1,0.38,0.38) legend:Category_5_=_≥205_km/h_(≥128_mph)_(5) Backgroundcolors = canvas:canvas BarData = barset:Hurricane bar:Month PlotData= barset:Hurricane width:10 align:left fontsize:S shift:(4,-4) anchor:till from:12/01/1996 till:19/01/1996 color:C1 text:"Yasi" from:12/02/1996 till:14/02/1996 color:TD text:"TD" from:22/02/1996 till:23/02/1996 color:TD text:"TD" from:09/03/1996 till:11/03/1996 color:C1 text:"Zaka" from:10/03/1996 till:13/03/1996 color:C1 text:"Atu" from:21/03/1996 till:29/03/1996 color:C4 text:"Beti" bar:Month width:5 align:center fontsize:S shift:(0,-20) anchor:middle color:canvas from:01/01/1996 till:31/01/1996 text:January from:01/02/1996 till:28/02/1996 text:February from:01/03/1996 till:31/03/1996 text:March TextData = pos:(569,23) text:"(For further details, please see" pos:(713,23) text:"[[Tropical cyclone scales#Australia and Fiji|scales]])"
{| class="toccolours" cellspacing="0" style="float:right; margin-left:1em;" |- style="background:#ccccff" ! Record !! [[Tropical cyclone|Tropical
Cyclone]] !! [[Severe Tropical Cyclone|Severe Tropical
Cyclone]] !!
Ref |- | Average activity: (1969–70 – 1994–95) || align=right|7 – 8 || align=right|4 ||{{cite journal|publisher=Bureau of Meteorology|title=The South Pacific and Southeast Indian Ocean Tropical Cyclone Season 1997–98|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/amm/docs/2000/chappel.pdf|accessdate=May 29, 2011|author2=Bate P W|author1=Chappel L C|date=June 2, 2000|volume=49|pages=121–138|journal=Australian Meteorological and Oceanographic Journal|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5z4G6y3zj?url=http://www.bom.gov.au/amm/docs/2000/chappel%2Epdf |archivedate= May 30, 2011 |deadurl=no}} |- | ''Record high activity:'' || align="right"|[[1982–83 South Pacific cyclone season|1982–83]]: 14 || align="right"|[[1982–83 South Pacific cyclone season|1982–83]]:10 ||{{cite report|publisher=Fiji Meteorological Service |title=Tropical Cyclone Guidance for Season 2010/11 for the Fiji and the Southwest Pacific |url=http://www.met.gov.fj/2010_2011%20TC%20Guide.pdf |date=October 26, 2010 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/65kvh9FwY?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.met.gov.fj%2F2010_2011%2520TC%2520Guide.pdf |author=Climate Services Division |accessdate=April 6, 2012 |archivedate=February 27, 2012 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} |- | ''Record low activity'' || align=right|[[1994–95 South Pacific cyclone season|1994–95]]: 3 || align=right|[[1994–95 South Pacific cyclone season|1994–95]]: 0 || |- | ''Activity during this season:'' || align=right|4 || align=right|1 || |} Because of a weak–moderate [[La Niña]] episode, most tropical cyclones that developed within the season occurred within the Coral Sea.{{cite journal|volume=127|year=1999|journal=Monthly Weather Review|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1999)127<1274:EHTCO>2.0.CO;2|issn=1520-0493|pages=1297–1299|title=Eastern Hemisphere Tropical Cyclones of 1996|author2=Trehubenko, Eric J|author3=Guard, Charles P|author=Lander, Mark A|issue=6|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/1520-0493%281999%29127%3C1274%3AEHTCO%3E2.0.CO%3B2|publisher=American Meteorological Society|bibcode=1999MWRv..127.1274L|accessdate=July 20, 2011}}{{cite journal|author=Callaghan, Jeff|volume=46|pages=325–339|date=December 4, 1997|publisher=Australian Bureau of Meteorology|title=The South Pacific and Southeast Indian Ocean Tropical Cyclone Season 1995-96|journal=Australian Meteorological and Oceanographic Journal|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/amm/docs/1997/callaghan.pdf|accessdate=May 23, 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/65ZyJIEY4?url=http://www.bom.gov.au/amm/docs/1997/callaghan%2Epdf |archivedate= February 19, 2012 |deadurl=no}} The weak La Nina also affected the amount of tropical cyclones that occurred during the year with only 4 tropical cyclones occurring the season as a whole became one of the most inactive tropical cyclone seasons since 1969-70. The first tropical cyclone of the season, Yasi, developed on January 12 as a tropical depression before it was named on January 16. As a tropical cyclone, Yasi brought significant rain to both Fiji and Tonga before it dissipated on January 19 to the south of Papette in French Polynesia. After Yasi dissipated, no tropical cyclones were recorded in the basin until March 9; however on February 12, a tropical low developed to the west of New Caledonia. Over the next 24 hours the low deepened to about 1002 hPa before it crossed 160°E and moved into the Australian region where it became known as the Queen Elizabeth II storm. On February 22 and 23, a shallow tropical depression moved around the Fijian archipelago and caused some flooding of low-lying areas in Vanua Levu.{{cite web|title=Flooding in the Fiji Islands between 1840 and 2009|publisher=Risk Frontiers|author=McGree, Simon|author2=Yeo, Stephen W.|page=41|author3=Devi, Swastika|url=http://www.riskfrontiers.com/RFfrontimages/Floods%20in%20Fiji%201840-2009%20-%20Risk%20Frontiers%20final.pdf|date=October 1, 2010|accessdate=June 24, 2011}} On March 9 and 10, Tropical Cyclones Zaka and Atu both developed near New Caledonia, about {{Convert|1000|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=5}} apart and took similar tracks towards the southeast before becoming extratropical. On March 21, the final tropical cyclone of the season developed to the northeast of Vanuatu. Over the next couple of days the depression gradually developed further and was named as Beti, before it passed over Vanuatu and New Caledonia. On March 29, after it had passed over New Caledonia, Beti degenerated into an extratropical cyclone, before dissipating on April 2. After the season ended the name Beti was retired from the tropical cyclone naming lists. ==Storms== ===Tropical Cyclone Yasi=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=SPac |Image=Cyclone Yasi 1996.png |Track=Yasi 1996 track.png |1-min winds=45 |10-min winds=45 |Pressure=987 |Formed=January 12 |Dissipated=January 19 }} On January 12, RSMC Nadi reported that a tropical depression had developed over the Fijian island of [[Vanua Levu]], about 430 km (270 mi) to the south of [[Labasa]]. Over the next few days, the depression moved towards the southeast before it started to affect Tonga on January 15.{{TCWC Wellington BT}} During the following day, the depression rapidly developed further as it interacted with the [[South Pacific Convergence Zone]], before the NPMOC initiated warnings on the system and designated it as 08P. At 0000 UTC on January 17, the NPMOC reported that the depression had reached its peak 1-minute sustained windspeeds of 85 km/h (50 mph) while RSMC Nadi reported that the depression had intensified into a tropical cyclone while it was located about 510 km (320 mi) to the southeast of [[Nukualofa]], Tonga. However RSMC Nadi did not name it Yasi for another 12 hours, while the system reached its peak 10-minute sustained windspeeds of 85 km/h (50 mph). After it was named on January 17, Yasi accelerated towards the southeast, before it moved out of RSMC Nadi's area of responsibility. During January 18, the NPMOC issued their final warning because Yasi had degenerated into an extratropical cyclone. TCWC Wellington monitored Yasi's remnants for another day, before they dissipated about 1520 km (940 mi) to the south of [[Tahiti|Papette]], [[French Polynesia]]. Although no major damage was reported from any of the islands affected some minor damage was reported in Tonga, after Yasi caused heavy rainfall there.{{cite web|date=September 17, 2008|accessdate=June 2, 2011|title=Event Information: Tropical Cyclone Yasi|archivedate=June 2, 2011|url=http://www.pacificdisaster.net/pdn2008/ExportPdfServlet?header=Event%20Information&sql=Select%20*%20From%20Event%20Where%20Id=250&photo=|publisher=Pacific Disaster.Net|author=Barr, Joe|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5z8XXuO5B}} {{Clear}} ===Tropical Cyclone Zaka=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=SPac |Image=Cyclone Zaka 1996.png |Track=Zaka 1996 track.png |1-min winds=40 |10-min winds=35 |Pressure=995 |Formed=March 9 |Dissipated=March 11 }} On March 9, RSMC Nadi started to monitor a tropical depression had developed within an [[South Pacific Convergence Zone|active convergence zone]], about 150 km (95 mi) to the northwest of [[Noumea, New Caledonia]]. During that day an [[trough (meteorology)|upper level trough]] moved over New Zealand which brought the [[jet stream]] over New Caledonia. As a result, this made the depression hard to locate with satellite imagery. However, later that day despite the system being poorly organized, RSMC Nadi reported that the depression had intensified into a tropical cyclone and named it Zaka. As they named it RSMC Nadi reported that the system had reached its peak 10-minute sustained windspeeds of 65 km/h (40 mph) with further development of the system restricted by strong vertical wind shear.{{cite web|title=RSMC Nadi Best Track Data for the 1995-96 season|url=ftp://eclipse.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/ibtracs/original-bt-data-files/nadi/RSMC%20Nadi%209596%20BT%20Data.txt.txt|accessdate=June 3, 2011|author=RSMC Nadi — Tropical Cyclone Centre|date=September 17, 2008|work=Fiji Meteorological Service|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration}} Early on March 10, the JTWC designated Zaka as Tropical Cyclone 20P, while it had its peak 1-minute windspeeds of 75 km/h (45 mph). RSMC Nadi then issued their final advisory at 0600 UTC, as Zaka had weakened into a tropical depression and was moving into TCWC Wellingtons area of responsibility. TCWC Wellington and the JTWC monitored Zaka for another day before it was last noted during March 11 as it became an extratropical cyclone.{{cite web|title=Weekly tropical cyclone summary #241 March 3 - 10 1996|author=Beven, Jack|url=https://groups.google.com/group/sci.geo.meteorology/browse_thread/thread/7eaa7d69ea90b3fd/ff35e614adb9b50b?|date=December 24, 1994|publisher=Google Groups|accessdate=May 17, 2011}} Zaka dumped {{Convert|376|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rain on Vanuatu in just 24 hours.{{cite news|title=Weatherwatch|author=Thwaytes, Robin|date=March 12, 1996|newspaper=The Guardian|pages=Features: T14}} (Accessed through LexisNexis) {{Clear}} ===Tropical Cyclone Atu=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=SPac |Image=Cyclone_Atu_1996.png |Track=Atu 1996 track.png |1-min winds=55 |10-min winds=55 |Pressure=987 |Formed=March 10 |Dissipated=March 13 }} On March 4, the JTWC started to monitor an area of disturbed weather that had developed within the Australian region about 900 km (560 mi), to the southeast of [[Port Moresby]] in [[Papua New Guinea]].{{cite web|url=http://www.usno.navy.mil/NOOC/nmfc-ph/RSS/jtwc/best_tracks/1996/1996s-bsh/bsh211996.txt|accessdate=June 25, 2011|author2=Joint Typhoon Warning Center|title=Tropical Cyclone 21P (Atu) best track analysis|author=Naval Pacific Meteorology and Oceanography Centre|date=December 17, 2002|publisher=United States Navy, United States Airforce}} Over the next few days, the system remained weak and gradually moved southeast before it crossed 160°E and moved into the basin on March 9. During the next day, both the JTWC and RSMC Nadi started to monitor the system as a tropical depression as it moved through the [[Loyalty Islands]]. On March 11, the depression intensified into a tropical cyclone as it moved southeastward, prompting RSMC Nadi to name it Atu at 1800 UTC. Early on March 12, the JTWC reported that Atu had reached its peak 1-minute windspeeds of 100 km/h (65 mph). Later that morning RSMC Nadi reported that Atu had reached its peak 10-minute sustained windspeeds of 85 km/h (50 mph). After it had peaked in intensity, Atu weakened under the influence of strong vertical windshear before the JTWC and RSMC Nadi issued their final advisories during March 13 as Atu had become extratropical. Atu's remnants were then monitored by RSMC Nadi and TCWC Wellington until they dissipated on March 18. {{Clear}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} ===Severe Tropical Cyclone Beti=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=SPac |Image=Cyclone Beti 1996.png |Track=Beti 1996 track.png |1-min winds=105 |10-min winds=90 |Pressure=935 |Formed=March 21 |Dissipated=March 28 }} On March 19, the JTWC started to monitor a tropical disturbance that was located about 1145 km (710 mi) to the northwest of [[Suva|Suva, Fiji]].{{cite web|year=1996|title=Tropical Cyclone 23P (Beti) best track analysis|url=http://www.usno.navy.mil/NOOC/nmfc-ph/RSS/jtwc/best_tracks/1996/1996s-bsh/bsh231996.txt|author=Naval Pacific Meteorology and Oceanography Centre|author2=Joint Typhoon Warning Center|accessdate=June 16, 2011|publisher=United States Navy, United States Airforce}} Over the next couple of days the system moved towards the south and gradually developed further in an area of low vertical windshear, before the system was designated as Tropical Depression 23P by the JTWC and RSMC Nadi on March 21. Over the next couple of days, 23P moved further towards the south, before the depression started to move towards the southwest as a ridge of high pressure strengthened on March 23. Later that day, RSMC Nadi reported that the depression had intensified into a category 1 tropical cyclone and named it as Beti. During that day, Beti continued to develop further before the system moved into the [[Coral Sea]] on March 24, after passing over the Vanuatuan islands of [[Pentecost Island|Pentecost]] and [[Malekula Island|Malekula]]. As Beti moved into the Coral Sea, the system quickly intensified further, with RSMC Nadi reporting on March 25 that Beti had intensified into a category 3 severe tropical cyclone. As Beti intensified into a severe tropical cyclone, the ridge of high pressure weakened as it interacted with an upper level trough of low pressure. As a result, the system started to move towards the south-southeast. Over the next couple of days Beti continued to intensify as it moved towards New Caledonia, before the JTWC reported at 1800 UTC on March 26, that Beti had reached its peak 1-minute sustained windspeeds of 195 km/h (120 mph). Six hours later, RSMC Nadi reported that the system had peaked as a category 4 severe tropical cyclone with 10-minute sustained windspeeds of 165 km/h (105 mph). Later on March 27, Severe Tropical Cyclone Beti made landfall on the [[New Caledonia|Grande Terre island]] of New Caledonia near its peak intensity and quickly weakened into a category 2 tropical cyclone. During the next day, Beti moved towards the southeast under the influence of the trough, reemerging into the Coral Sea as a weakening tropical cyclone that had started to transition into an extratropical cyclone. Later on March 28, RSMC Nadi passed the primary warning responsibility of the cyclone to TCWC Wellington, before the JTWC issued their final advisory on Beti as it had become extratropical. Over the next few days, TCWC Wellington continued to monitor Beti's remnants, as they came under the influence of a high pressure area and moved around New Zealand's East Coast, before they were last noted on April 2 while located about 1400 km (870 mi) to the southeast of Wellington. While it was active, Cyclone Beti was responsible for 2 deaths and caused damage in Australia, New Caledonia, New Zealand, and Vanuatu. The most significant damage occurred in New Caledonia where wind and flooding destroyed crops, gardens and caused disruption to the electricity network, water supply, road and telephone communications.{{cite web|url=http://www.ausaid.gov.au/publications/focus/focuspdfs/2964-9.pdf?q=focus-4|date=July 25, 1996|accessdate=June 22, 2011|title=Focus — New Caledonia Cyclone|publisher=Australian Agency for International Development}} Many homes and roads were also badly damaged, with over 50% of lower standard housing on the outskirts of Noumea damaged after rivers and creeks burst their banks.{{cite web|year=2010|accessdate=June 22, 2011|url=http://www.meteo.nc/cyclone/cyclones-passes|publisher=Meteo France Nouvelle-Calédonie|title=Cyclone passes — Cyclone Beti| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110626063803/http://meteo.nc/cyclone/cyclones-passes|archivedate=June 26, 2011|deadurl=no}} Press reports indicated that Beti inflicted between [[French Francs|FF]] 22-{{ntsp|27000000}} (US$4.3 - {{ntsp|5300000}}) in damage to New Caledonia and that only a few injuries had occurred.{{#tag:ref|This damage total was originally reported in [[French franc]]s and was converted to United States Dollars via the [[Oanda Corporation]] website.{{cite web|publisher=Oanda Corporation|year=2013|title=Historical Exchange Rates|accessdate=January 27, 2013|url=http://www.oanda.com/currency/historical-rates/}}|group="nb"|name="FF to USD"}} Within Vanuatu, Beti caused about {{ntsp|4500000||[[Vanuatu vatu|VUV]]}}, ({{ntsp|41000||US$}}) in damage to food gardens and shelters.{{#tag:ref|This damage total was originally reported in United States Dollars and was converted to [[Vanuatu vatu]]s via the [[Oanda Corporation]] website.|group="nb"|name="USD to VUV"}}{{cite web|author2=Prasad, Binman |title=Economic Impact of Natural Disasters on development in the Pacific Volume 1: Research Report |accessdate=June 29, 2010 |archivedate=February 25, 2010 |pages=10–89 |author3=Kaloumaira, Atu |publisher=South Pacific Applied Geoscience Commission |author=McKenzie, Emily |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5noEcWKP4?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.pacificdisaster.net%2Fpdnadmin%2Fdata%2Foriginal%2Feconomic%2520impact%2520of%2520natural%2520disasters%2520on%2520development%2520in%2520the%2520pacific.pdf |url=http://www.pacificdisaster.net/pdnadmin/data/original/economic%20impact%20of%20natural%20disasters%20on%20development%20in%20the%20pacific.pdf |year=2005 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}{{cite report|title=Report of the WMO Post-Tropical Cyclone "Pam" Expert Mission to Vanuatu|publisher=World Meteorological Organization|page=22|url=http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/dra/documents/WMO-Pam-mission-Apri-2015-FinalReport.pdf}} As an [[extratropical cyclone]], Beti generated a high surf and long period swells that hit both eastern Australia and New Zealand. Within Australia, the high surf left several competitors in the Australian life surfing championships injured, while another competitor was killed after his boat was swamped by large waves.{{cite news|publisher=The Australian |author2=Owens, Jared |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/sport/teenager-ironman-dies-at-surf-lifesaving-titles/story-e6frg7mf-1225843014728 |accessdate=June 22, 2011 |archivedate=June 26, 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5zij6E0xG?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.theaustralian.com.au%2Fnews%2Fsport%2Fteenager-ironman-dies-at-surf-lifesaving-titles%2Fstory-e6frg7mf-1225843014728 |title=Teenage ironman Saxon Bird dies at surf life saving titles |author=Barrett, Rossanne |date=March 20, 2010 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Within New Zealand, Beti's remnants caused flooding and mud-slips, which led to several roads being closed. A helicopter and its pilot were lost at the height of the storm, while they were travelling from [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]] to [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]]. {{Clear}} ==Seasonal effects== {{Pacific areas affected (Top)}} |- | {{Sort|00|Yasi}} || {{Sort|0112|January 12 – 19}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A1}}|{{Sort|1|Category 1 tropical cyclone}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A1}}|{{Sort|85|85 km/h (50 mph)}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A1}}|{{Sort|987|987 hPa (29.15 inHg)}} || Fiji, Tonga || Minor || None || |- | {{Sort|01|TD}} || {{Sort|0212|February 12 – 14}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|TD}}|{{Sort|0|Tropical depression}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|low}}|{{Sort|0|Not Specified}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|low}}|{{Sort|999|Not Specified}} || None || None || None || |- | {{Sort|02|TD}} || {{Sort|0222|February 22 – 24}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|TD}}|{{Sort|0|Shallow tropical depression}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|TD}}|{{Sort|0|Not Specified}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|TD}}|{{Sort|999|Not Specified}} || Fiji || Minor || None || |- | {{sort|03|Zaka}} || {{Sort|0309|March 9 – 11}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A1}}|{{Sort|1|Category 1 tropical cyclone}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A1}}|{{Sort|65|65 km/h (45 mph)}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A1}}|{{Sort|993|993 hPa (29.33 inHg)}} || New Caledonia || Minor || None || |- | {{Sort|04|Atu}} || {{Sort|0310|March 10 – 13}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A1}}|{{Sort|1|Category 1 tropical cyclone}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A1}}|{{Sort|85|85 km/h (50 mph)}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A1}}|{{Sort|987|987 hPa (29.15 inHg)}} || New Caledonia || Minor || None || |- | {{Sort|05|Beti}} || {{Sort|0321|March 21 – 28}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A4}}|{{Sort|4|Category 4 severe tropical cyclone}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A4}}|{{Sort|99|165 km/h (105 mph)}} || bgcolor=#{{storm colour|A4}}|{{Sort|935|935 hPa (27.61 inHg)}} || Australia, Vanuatu
New Caledonia, New Zealand || {{ntsp|5300000||$}} || 2 || |- {{TC Areas affected (Bottom)|TC's=6 systems|dates=January 12 – March 28|winds=165 km/h (105 mph)|pres=935 hPa (27.61 inHg)|damage={{ntsp|5600000}}|deaths=2|Refs=}} ==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} *Atlantic hurricane seasons: [[1995 Atlantic hurricane season|1995]], [[1995 Atlantic hurricane season|1996]] *Pacific hurricane seasons: [[1995 Pacific hurricane season|1995]], [[1995 Pacific hurricane season|1996]] *Pacific typhoon seasons: [[1995 Pacific typhoon season|1995]], [[1996 Pacific typhoon season|1996]] *North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons: [[1995 North Indian Ocean cyclone season|1995]], [[1996 North Indian Ocean cyclone season|1996]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{SPAC EL's}} {{TC Decades|Year=1990|basin=South Pacific|type=cyclone|shem=yes}} {{1995–96 South Pacific cyclone season buttons}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1995-96 South Pacific cyclone season}} [[Category:1995–96 South Pacific cyclone season]] [[Category:South Pacific cyclone seasons]] [[Category:Articles which contain graphical timelines]]
